txt.en: 'I fear my people may not endure them both, and so, I beg your aid.'
'The keen eyes of your people may reveal secrets of great import.'
'They may decide the fate of Durin's Folk.'
'I shall honour the old ways of Thrór and Carc.'
Instance: An Unexpected Summons
'You will have the thanks of Durin's Folk, and all that your people desire.'
'This oath I swear.'
Arcah looses a cry, and the ravens of Ravenhill fly forth!
'Come, [placeholder].'
'Despite these unexpected tidings, you honour me with your summons. It seems I now seek your audience!'
'Let us learn for what purpose Dís has summoned us.'
'Hail, King under the Mountain.'
'I am Arcah, Daughter of Croär, chief of my people.'
'Thorin... curious.'
'It has been many years since I dwelt in the shadow of the Mountain.'
'When I was not long from my egg, Roäc was chief.'
'He knew friendship with your people, and he had not forgotten the Kings of old.'
'I have not forgotten them either.'
'And now I shall answer your question, King under the Mountain.'
'The last King of your name left Roäc in anger, and he dishonoured the friendship between our peoples.'
'At long last, one of the line of Croär and Roäc has returned to Ravenhill.'
'Though it may not be remembered thus among the folk of Durin, it is thus remembered to us.'
'And now, you too have come.'
'This is why I seek your audience.'
'Shall you prove different, Thorin Stonehelm?'
'I would see the friendship between our peoples strengthened once more.'
'If this you swear, I shall do as you bid.'
'Very well.'
'Yet, I must know, who is your companion?'
'I have come, Dís.'
'You have made a promise, King under the Mountain.'
'I trust you speak true.'
'Why have you summoned me to Ravenhill?'
'I have sent my people to spy upon your foes in the North.'
'When they return, you will know as they know.'
'I have spoken.'
Dís reveals a wooden whistle and its shrill call echoes through Ravenhill
'I am Thorin Stonehelm, third of my name.'
'Why now do you seek an audience with me?'
'I cannot answer for the hurts my forebear brought upon you.'
'I knew only that your people lent us great aid in times of both peace and strife.'
'An old foe of my people, a cold-drake, shall soon come to Erebor.'
'He was drawn hither by a Man of unusual longevity named Karazgar.'
